text:
<@UC6997THT> YouTube is a bit bigger than GitHub and has monetization and recommendation and – most importantly – is engaging in a fundamentally different way.  Perhaps the common element is that they are online platforms were people put stuff.  (This does make them a little less similar to online platforms where people primarily do stuff e.g. play games or discuss stuff e.g. right here).  I'd claim that monetization is less important than the other differences.

Now about you Unity plugin, this is perfect example of how a dollar isn't worth a dollar and how cost/benefit tradeoffs lead to sort of market failure, at least a dollar priced market failure: the responsibility of accepting just isn't worth it $5-$25.  For example I think the primary way people "pay" for Open Source libraries is in dedicating their attention to learn and use them.

text: And if that's the case, then perhaps Stack Overflow is the real marketplace.

elements.text: And if that's the case, then perhaps Stack Overflow is the real marketplace.

text:
let me also add there's a "spirit of giving". I contribute to open source for free because I've received so many other open source things for free. I get that some projects need funding like say openssl 

but I recently managed to get a contract to do some open source work and I feel like I can't mention I'm getting paid otherwise contributors might feel like not contributing unless they also get paid. maybe that's fair but it does point out yet another complication

text:
I don’t know. If I buy a t-shirt, and I care about good fit, the quality, which materials were used, where it was produced, and if it was sewn by a child or not, I run into very similar trust issues you described earlier for software. It’s not a difference of “old economy” vs. knowledge work, it’s a difference of whether you care or not.

For software I can also just accept dubios metrics (price, number of stars on GitHub, lines of code, etc.). Or I care enough to not accept those and realize that reality is always more complex than the oversimplified metrics we use everywhere to not have to deal with reality’s complexities — and markets are such a mechanism where we let an open market figure out one such metric, price.

text:
Knowledge work is different, because it doesn’t involve materials. The materials required to produce knowledge work cost next to nothing, because we in our comfortable western world already have all the equipment we need and can just spend time on turning thoughts into running programs.

Something that’s easily exploitable by businesses who are desperate to find new markets by telling employees that they can work on what they want one day a week or at a company hackathon and then had them sign agreements before that mean that every idea and product that comes out of it is intellectual property owned by the organisation. (Not saying that every 20% rule or hackathon are motivated by this, just pointing out that it’s possible.)

elements.text:

(Not saying that every 20% rule or hackathon are motivated by this, just pointing out that it’s possible.)

text:
I don’t think a hypothetical statement about the future can be a statement of fact. It can be a hypothesis (that is hard or impossible to test), and as such I was pointing out why I think it’s not true.

YouTube chose a certain model to scale, and it’s the model they chose (monetizing people’s attention with ads) that incentivizes quantity over quality, and that brought all the people who don’t actually want to create value, because it’s so easy to get people’s attention with BS. It’s not money that made YouTube worse, it’s the ad-based business model monetizing viewers attention that did.

HBO and Netflix have a different model that at least incentivized them to produce high-quality content so people are willing to pay for a monthly subscription, because they love watching Game of Thrones or Westworld.

I don’t know what a good model for software could be. But if it needs to be scalable, it’ll involve money in one way or another, at least until we end up in that post-capitalism world they have in Star Trek.

It’s not money that made YouTube worse, it’s the ad-based business model monetizing viewers attention that did.

HBO and Netflix have a different model that at least incentivized them to produce high-quality content so people are willing to pay for a monthly subscription, because they love watching Game of Thrones or Westworld.

I don’t know what a good model for software could be. But if it needs to be scalable, it’ll involve money in one way or another, at least until we end up in that post-capitalism world they have in Star Trek.

text:
It sounds like you're more anti-money then me! :joy: You're right that there are always non-monetary concerns. But with software these concerns directly affect the consumer, albeit after some delay. Hmm, arguably climate change is the same though the delay is a little greater. Not the fight I've chosen, but I'm definitely glad others care about these issues.

You're right that it depends on the business model. I don't claim a solution has to not involve money. I just claim that merely adding money to an existing business model isn't always going to improve things. Maybe that's our point of agreement?

The whole point of money has been that it made the incommensurable commensurable. If that is becoming increasingly untrue then the role of money is arguably becoming a lot less central to the economy. We need to be teaching kids and people to think more about business models and supply chains.

text:
While I disagree with <@UA14TGLTC>'s comment about the monetization angle being unimportant, the observation of relative scale of YouTube and GitHub is extremely relevant here, and also to the side thread on business models and supply chains (<https://futureprogramming.slack.com/archives/C5T9GPWFL/p1539470382000100;> thanks <@U5STGTB3J> for engaging with me). As non-monetary concerns grow in importance, it becomes harder to reason about those concerns. I think that imposes a limit on how complex business models can get if you also care about the quality of creation (particularly for 'soft' products like videos or software), or about things like ethical sourcing and CO2 emissions.

Modern supply chains are incredibly complex: <https://logicmag.io/04-see-no-evil>. Hard to imagine they come out unscathed if we start caring about more than money. The recent fracas about SoftMicro and hardware security is another example here.

attachments.fallback:
[October 13th, 2018 3:39 PM] stefanlesser: <@UCUSW7WVD> Interesting. I’m trying to wrap my head around tasks where extrinsic incentives work well according to your definition — do you have an example for what you had in mind?

And if I understand you correctly, you mean that writing software does not fall into that category?
Does that mean you are arguing software shouldn’t be sold (for money)?

And I have to admit that you lost me at the end with passion and motivation… to me it sounds like the best word for what you describe is _trust_. But I’m not sure where that connects to the original thought about money.

Going back to <@UC6997THT>’s YouTube example: I think “YouTube would be 1000x better without money” triggered my response, because I think it’s very easy to make the mistake of only seeing the negative side of money, the corruption, the misguided incentives (based on making money over delivering value), and all the business-types who show up that we’d rather like to stay home. But that’s unfortunately how markets work. If there is value, people will come and try to exploit that. But it also paves the way and breaks down barriers of entry for everyone, making it possible for real value creators and those who just want to express themselves to contribute. The money amplifies or accelerates both the good and the bad parts. One comes with the other. Even if we’d only like to have the good parts.

attachments.title: See No Evil
attachments.text: Software helps companies coordinate the supply chains that sustain global capitalism. How does the code work—and what does it conceal?

thanks

for engaging with me). As non-monetary concerns grow in importance, it becomes harder to reason about those concerns. I think that imposes a limit on how complex business models can get if you also care about the quality of creation (particularly for 'soft' products like videos or software), or about things like ethical sourcing and CO2 emissions.

Modern supply chains are incredibly complex:
. Hard to imagine they come out unscathed if we start caring about more than money. The recent fracas about SoftMicro and hardware security is another example here.

text: …and consequences and incentives. Funny, now you point it out, I might’ve come across as defending capitalism, but you are absolutely right that I am very far on the other side and would like us to rather live in a Star Trek future. I just don’t think we can get there with blindly trusting idealism and by ignoring how the world works today.

Totally agreed!

text:
Since you brought up a scifi metaphors, and since the metaphors we use have a powerful effect on our desires and goals, I'll throw out a couple of scifi metaphors that have influenced me for years. Not pushing back on anything you said, just a _non sequitur_ in hopes of continuing the conversation.

a) While our hopes for the future tend to look like the _Enterprise_, all gleaming chrome and clean interfaces, I now hanker after something more like the _Serenity_ (<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kQtdfh2Uxoo>), all the wires and ductwork hanging out. While it's not as nice to look at, it seems far more hackable and democratic. Habitable. (<http://akkartik.name/post/habitability>)

b) Asimov's Second Foundation, as a sort of less tangible counterweight to the tangible technological advancement of the First Foundation. The First Foundation was technologically advanced like the Star Trek universe, but people were still recognizably people in their ethical and cognitive limitations. The Second Foundation was Asimov's attempt to envision a world of _better_ people. While he got the details understandably wrong (there's no reason to believe telepathy will make people better), I think there's something to the idea of changing ourselves to improve the efficacy of our tools. The change I imagine is to incentives. People already have huge incentives to not be anti-social, but only locally so. I'd like to live in a world where just as much attention goes to _global_ consequences of behavior. This is a technology problem too, but the solution will look very different from our usual examples of technology. It may well end up being as simple as a checklist.

text: Absolutely. We already have incentives without money. That's my whole point: in some areas we should emphasize non-monetary incentives.
